I especially loved the sneaky little spooky questions that they added in randomly. Definitely make you feel a bit uneasy, as you sit there alone in the dark taking The Test. I personally felt as if my ending word was accurate, and felt as if the narrator/game was giving me a bit of incite on my personality, and a little bit of reflection in shedding light on a way that I may not view myself or my personality. 143680103.review:
As stupid as the tests in various color magazines. 

For example: "Do you believe that you are worthy of someone's time investment?" - this is not a question to me, but to those around me, the alternative is to flip a coin or a cheesy ego test. Or "Do you fear spiders?" - no, I'm not afraid of spiders, I'm not 15 years old, I'm disgusted by them, and it's a completely different feeling. 

And this is just one example of many. Another might be a list of words that fit the situation, only that none of them fit the situation - and that answer is no longer there.

Of course, I didn't expect neural network level analysis, but this is just simply stupid. Such tests remind me of "psychology" for the poor from the 90's or class work for a high school science competition. The summary, on the other hand, made me laugh: if the authors knew how far they miss the mark.

PS
I'm not returning this production because I think it would be unfair, although honestly, I should do just that.

I'd played a free game made by the dev in this series, and liked it. This paid version, though cheap, is worth every penny. It's got a lot more content, while maintaining questions that make you think and a surprisingly insightful answer at the end. I love personality quizzes, so this was right up my alley. The quiz itself is pretty substantial; this listed playtime was from me doing it partially a couple times, then doing it from start to finish before leaving this review.

A quick note. While sometimes the game may freeze while still playing audio, this is a surprisingly common glitch of RPG Maker MV on newer systems. There is a quick and easy workaround that players can do to fix it, which I mentioned in a Discussion thread here. Literally changing one line in a game file using Notepad on Windows 10, found using ALT + F. So if the game locks up, don't give up. This experience is one worth troubleshooting.

130074318.review:
I've always had a soft spot for games that ask you series of questions (the personality quiz from the Pokemon Mystery Dungeon series comes to mind). While I watch other people play games in that niche, I do so to learn more about them (assuming they're answering honestly). I always wonder though: How would [i] I [/i] answer those same questions?
The Test is a simple game with a mysterious atmosphere. You're in a setting that would seem uncomfortable, but you're unable to move and all you can do is answer the questions that are given to you from an unknown source. These questions can all be answered inside of a half-hour, but there are laughs, disconcerting questions, and insight along the way.
At the end of the test, you are given a secret word, and a fairly lengthy explanation of how it relates to you. There are several words you can get, and they are all based on your answers. For example, my secret word was [spoiler] talented [/spoiler], but you are likely to get something different. It was actually really nice, and I am looking forward to playing other games in this same series!
Highly recommended, and would definitely play again! :)

129197033.review:
Order

Rest of the review is written by my partner who played it from my account, but I very much agree.

This game pretends to be a personality test pretending not to be a personality test.

As far as personality tests go, this one is not even good. "Which Color are you" kind of spam on facebook is usually better. I might feel more positive about it if I felt the result resonate, but ... that did not happen. In an attempt to be deep, this completely missed the mark. "im14andthisisdeep" level, basically.

Taken as a game, there is pretty much no gameplay? You answer mostly yes/no questions for 20 minutes. Some try to be creepy, but go about it in a way that completely failed to work on me. It needs better setup, better framing, go more slowly and more deliberately about building tension.

A lot of reviews imply that the questions induce self-reflection and thought. For that, the questions would need to be much deeper. As a 38 year old, i've known the basic answers to those questions since my teens I guess -- and the game did a bad job of inducing doubt and having me re-evaluate. So I went "yes" "yes" "no" "yes" "no" "blue" "just get to the point already".

Taken as a story, it looks like the format has potential. You could fit a lot of story into a game that is "only" asking you questions.
This one was executed badly. At no point it felt like the game is responding to my answers. At no point was there any allusion to the background image, or anything than the ""test"" itself really. If there was a story, I missed it completely, i.e., the game did a bad job of showing it.

125089953.review:
This game is brilliant in that it managed to game the Steam system. It gives people an overinflated sense of importance then tells them to review the game and give their “special word” in their review. Boosting their reviews artificially.

I’m gonna have trouble deciding on whether to rate this a yes or no, it’s honestly a 50/50 on if you should buy this for me. It’s a basic personality test. The questions are more interesting than your average test, but that’s what the game is under the surface. As for the horror aspects, there’s a few creepy questions. I recommend playing in a dark empty room if you want the full effect, and if you’re too scared to play then play it with a friend and that will basically completely eliminate the scare factor.

The major complaints I have are about the deception in the game and the oddness of the ending. As for the deception, I already discussed the review thing, but without getting into the specifics the game will also tell you that your results are determined through a thorough process. I’m 99% sure this is untrue because there doesn’t seem to be any variation of results based on anything but your answers to the questions as a few other reviewers have mentioned. And my word was “Blessing”, however I watched different play throughs and all of the results seem like your “basic personality test” results. Stuff that’s super generic and made to boost your ego so you are inclined to agree with it. And as for the ending, it just didn’t fit with the rest of the theme in my opinion.

Overall, I’m gonna give this game a thumbs up solely cause it’s only 2 dollars. I’d go as far as to say it should only be one dollar since it’s only about 30 minutes and there’s nothing graphical involved, but if you’re feeling down and want some motivation and a somewhat scary game then this is for you, can’t really go wrong for two bucks imo. But if you want some super unique game/social experiment to “reveal hidden truths” like the description implies, I wouldn’t count on it. Who knows though, maybe they’ll prove me wrong and the special words have a meaning and the algorithm is really detailed. However being they’ve made like 5 other games using the same exact formula I doubt it.

[h1] Overall, a pretty good ga- or, test, I suppose I should say. [/h1]

The game does have some good questions- some that make you think a tad bit deeply, but of course there's also some semi-generic ones, as well as a couple funni questions.

123784504.review:
Secret word: Greed (???)

Look. I'm not mad that it's greed, it just literally doesn't make sense. This is like those shitty quizzes we all used to take back in the day that gave us totally random answers that made no sense.

This test started out asking a bunch of weird, random-ass questions that weren't relevant in any way, and tried way too hard to be funny and creepy at the same time. It asks legit like 20 questions about "did you notice the last letter of the last 5 questions spells 'Satan'? Does that bother you?" No, I literally do not care, can we get to something more interesting yet? Feels like the devs put more time into being witty and clever with questions than actually getting the personality test up to scratch.

Look, I was honest with the questions. I can accept my failures, but they need to actually make sense. My secret word was greed. Greedy with what, I have no idea. I answered no to "are you good with money," and yes to "are you an only child," so maybe that's it lmao. The test reiterated later that I'm BAD with money (even though it asked me 1 question about it?) and that I better watch it.

At the end, the test tells you that the speed you answer questions is taken into factor. All I can think of is that that had something to do with it? I read fast and I want the result fast, so I'm greedy for instant payoff? Even though the devs wasted 20 of the 35 minutes on hiding the word 'Satan' in the text and asking about punching nuns.

Whoever thought up all that stuff should add the word "Egotistical" to their next game so their own crappy test can assign it to them. At least that would be accurate.

123292696.review:
WARNING:  if you have struggled with breaks from reality in the past, this game could potentially trigger paranoid thoughts. Psychotic breaks are serious, and the developers should add a trigger warning.

The Test is, underneath its bizzare facade, a glorified Buzzfeed quizz with its endings seemingly originating from a coaching seminar. A disturbing atmosphere and peculiar, sometimes creepy questions, seek to make the player feel uneasy, as if something sinister is going on. A fun little time killer, but what this game claims to be is untrue at best, and deceptive at worst. The most intelligent part of this test is where it asks you if x is your favorite y, and later on it asks you what your favorite y is, and your answer might be something contradicting your answer to the first question. Hardly a useful metric for delving deep into someone's psyche. The answers you get at the end of the game are something akin to what Jordan Peterson might say about tidying your room. I contemplated getting a refund, but at this price point, I can't justify that, as it was ultimately an interesting experience. If someone gets a better life out of playing this game, that's great. But if you're skeptical of this game, your skepticism is justified.

A classic example of the barnum effect.

120795344.review:
Chaos, thy name is me!

I'll be honest (because this is what the program demands of you) I'm mixed on this one. As many have noted, calling this a game is not fitting. Being sold via Steam makes one believe it will be a game, when it is exactly what it is titled a TEST.

Nothing is hidden if you read these reviews. You will simply be asked a wide variety of questions, which you are to answer truthfully, and over the course of about 20 minutes you'll get some advice.

PROs: 

1. This activity is enjoyable overall. Being asked many questions, some of which are not so obvious as to why they're being asked, is fun in the moment. 
2. The test seems like it may have some reliability to it in the sense that the same question is asked in differing ways to see if you keep answering honestly.
3. The simple music helps to add gravity to things. 

CONs:

1. No re-usability. Not really. You can redo this "game" and answer untruthfully I suppose to see what alternate advice you get. (I may do this because I feel the advice is very likely to be similar.)
2. Short. If you look at the reviews, no one is really clocking in at over an hour.

MIXED: 

1. 2 dollars seems a buck too much. But, developers deserve whatever they can get. 
2. I felt the advice given to me was incorrect. I know myself well and I do not mean this simply because who else can one know as well as yourself. I mean this because I've learned over the years to confront my good and less-than-good qualities head on.  Some I've leaned into and honed better and some I've learned to curb or even outright change. Some, sorry but as the great philosopher Popeye once said, "I yam's what I yam's". I'd love to explain why the advice seems wrong for me based on my honest answers but I dislike when people reveal things that should be kept secret. Even when the spoiler label is given it's too tempting or easy for eyes to roam and discover things. 

Like so many before me, if I could give this a mixed recommendation I would. I cannot so I will support the idea of it with a thumbs up.
